subject: Psychology
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course or subject?

My fascination with the human mind and behaviour began on the day my mother fell ill, my emotions took over me and I sought to understand the drivers behind these complex feelings. I turned to psychology. 'Psychology Review' magazines combined with articles from 'Psychology Today' provided me with some answers. They allowed me to better understand my previously confusing emotions and solidify my appreciation for the study of human nature. The magazines enabled me to understand psychology's shifting research spotlight. However, reading several volumes made me realise that the subject's young nature leaves much ambiguity in explaining intricate behaviours. Each new discovery since the development of the study of the relationship between mind and behaviour within psychology has unveiled important findings on the nature of humans and yet also reveals just how little we know about it. The way that each credible, well-tested approach could be challenged by alternatives with differing strengths, captivated me.

How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?

In my EPQ, I considered cognitive psychological theory and its applications, integrating findings from articles, books. I was able to apply my polished writing skills from being a monthly blog writer for a therapy clinic while developing my understanding of psychology's real world use. My role leading the diversity sub-committee, planning our school's culture week let me demonstrate my creativity and problem solving skills in addition to the perseverance and capability to see them through. While my initial A-level results did not reflect my true ability, the experience has driven me to refine my approach in order for me to get the best results I know I can achieve. This shift in mindset and motivation helped me optimise and develop a consistent and disciplined work ethic demonstrated by my ability to balance maintaining high quality standards in my academic studies, endorsed by teachers, alongside my two part time jobs.

What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?

Work experience within primary school and my part time job as a teaching assistant sparked my interest in how the principles of psychology are used to tailor education to each child's assessed cognitive development. This led me to an article by Eleanor Leigh that outlined the importance of addressing early-age psychological barriers to learning, to promote long-term wellbeing and success. The discovery showed me that psychology is all around us and sparked a newfound respect for the cognitive aspect of psychology. I then read Daniel Kahneman's 'Thinking, Fast and Slow', which developed my understanding of concepts like different thinking systems and cognitive tendencies. I learnt more on this topic when discussing with the director of 'Bristol CBT Clinic' during work experience with them. Outcomes of CBT consultations and assessments gave me insights into the clinic's operations and its use of cognitive strategies to disrupt unhealthy thought patterns. I worked with CBT therapists and trainee clinical psychologists to design a survey to identify traits linked with social anxiety for patient treatment. After reading Bryan Cook's, 'The Importance of Evidence-based Practice', I understand that if you wish to draw conclusions they need to be backed up by evidence. I initially began a small experiment on one participant to investigate the phonological similarity effect. Further, in my summer group project, I investigated the relationship between ASD and dyslexia and used an AQ test and nonsense reading task on 21 participants to measure the two disorders. We found a positive correlation, foreshadowed by a range of past studies. However the experiment introduced me to issues like co-morbidity and the difficulties of quantifying such unique and complicated disorders. This, along with reading Ben Goldacre's 'Bad Science' taught me about the importance of scientifically credible experiments and awareness of cognitive biases. The profound complexity of human behaviour and endless potential to uncover new truths about ourselves drives me to understand and explore beyond the boundaries of what we know. My journey so far has only deepened my resolve to comprehend the link between mind and behaviour.

feedback_items.weak_passage: 'Psychology Review' magazines combined with articles from 'Psychology Today' provided me with some answers.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is not specific enough - it's like saying 'I'm interested in Bible stories so I read the Bible' or 'I'm interested in economics so I've read various economics journals.' You need to be much more specific about what you actually read and what you learned from it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Name specific articles or volumes and explain what academic insights they provided. Take the reader through your academic understanding and thought process with concrete examples.

feedback_items.weak_passage: They allowed me to better understand my previously confusing emotions and solidify my appreciation for the study of human nature.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Because you haven't been specific about what you read, this doesn't logically follow. You haven't explained the original stance or what specifically helped you understand your emotions, so the appreciation you mention feels unearned and vague.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain your original emotional confusion with specificity, then cite a particular article or concept that helped you understand it, creating a clear logical progression.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Each new discovery since the development of the study of the relationship between mind and behaviour within psychology has unveiled important findings on the nature of humans and yet also reveals just how little we know about it.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You unveiled important findings - what findings? Reveals just how little we know - what do we know and what don't we know? What is the relationship between mind and behaviour? What ambiguity specifically? What intricate behaviours? It could be anything - running into traffic or messing around in the classroom. There's not a single thing here that's specific, academic, or supported by source material.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace all of this vague language with specific examples of discoveries, clear definitions of what we understand versus what remains unknown, and concrete examples of the behaviors you're discussing.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My fascination with the human mind and behaviour began on the day my mother fell ill, my emotions took over me and I sought to understand the drivers behind these complex feelings. I turned to psychology. 'Psychology Review' magazines combined with articles from 'Psychology Today' provided me with some answers...The way that each credible, well-tested approach could be challenged by alternatives with differing strengths, captivated me.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This entire first paragraph could be summarized in one sentence: 'I became interested in psychology by reading X's article, which talked about the same illness that my mother struggled with.' Then you should explore that in an academic sense. Currently there's no academic argument, reasoning, or logic displayed - which is the biggest problem with this statement.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense the opening to one sentence about what sparked your interest, then immediately dive into a specific article or concept with academic depth, methodology, and your critical analysis of it.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In my EPQ, I considered cognitive psychological theory and its applications, integrating findings from articles, books.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I need to know what the articles are, what the books are, and what your main arguments were. You can't just say 'articles and books' without specificity.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Name the specific articles and books, explain your main thesis, and walk through your key arguments with supporting evidence.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I was able to apply my polished writing skills from being a monthly blog writer for a therapy clinic while developing my understanding of psychology's real world use. My role leading the diversity sub-committee, planning our school's culture week let me demonstrate my creativity and problem solving skills in addition to the perseverance and capability to see them through.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is just filler language and listing soft skills you believe you have. I need to see sources, arguments, conclusions, methodology from your EPQ, and limitations. This is about your academic journey, not a list of personal qualities.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the soft skills listing and replace with concrete academic content: what was your EPQ methodology, what were your key findings, what limitations did you identify, what conclusions did you reach?

feedback_items.weak_passage: While my initial A-level results did not reflect my true ability, the experience has driven me to refine my approach in order for me to get the best results I know I can achieve. This shift in mindset and motivation helped me optimise and develop a consistent and disciplined work ethic demonstrated by my ability to balance maintaining high quality standards in my academic studies, endorsed by teachers, alongside my two part time jobs.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't need to explain why you did badly in A Levels the first time - that can go in the reference if needed. People take gap years and retakes all the time, it's nothing to be concerned about. This is not a good use of space in your personal statement.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this entire section and use the space to develop your academic interests with specific sources and arguments instead.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Work experience within primary school and my part time job as a teaching assistant sparked my interest in how the principles of psychology are used to tailor education to each child's assessed cognitive development. This led me to an article by Eleanor Leigh that outlined the importance of addressing early-age psychological barriers to learning, to promote long-term wellbeing and success.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a nice sentence and a nice opening. I like the topic area. This is the first part where I'm seeing some development.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Work experience within primary school and my part time job as a teaching assistant sparked my interest in how the principles of psychology are used to tailor education to each child's assessed cognitive development. This led me to an article by Eleanor Leigh that outlined the importance of addressing early-age psychological barriers to learning, to promote long-term wellbeing and success.
feedback_items.why_strong: This section has good structure - it connects work experience to a specific academic source and topic area, showing how practical experience led to theoretical exploration.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I then read Daniel Kahneman's 'Thinking, Fast and Slow', which developed my understanding of concepts like different thinking systems and cognitive tendencies.
feedback_items.your_feedback: It's great that you brought in this book, but 'different thinking systems and cognitive tendencies' is quite vague. He talks about a lot of interesting things - if you just drew one out specifically, that would be better.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Pick one specific concept from Kahneman's book (like System 1 vs System 2 thinking, or a particular bias) and explain it with depth rather than giving vague descriptors.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I worked with CBT therapists and trainee clinical psychologists to design a survey to identify traits linked with social anxiety for patient treatment.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's good and nice, but I'd prefer one more sentence here to say what did the survey show? What did it find? Anything that you learned or anything that could have been done better?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add a sentence explaining the survey results, key findings, or methodological insights you gained from this experience.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Further, in my summer group project, I investigated the relationship between ASD and dyslexia and used an AQ test and nonsense reading task on 21 participants to measure the two disorders. We found a positive correlation, foreshadowed by a range of past studies. However the experiment introduced me to issues like co-morbidity and the difficulties of quantifying such unique and complicated disorders. This, along with reading Ben Goldacre's 'Bad Science' taught me about the importance of scientifically credible experiments and awareness of cognitive biases.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole last paragraph is actually very well done. You mentioned actual surveys, gave specific details, told me what you found, identified issues, then linked it to a book and reached conclusions. Lots of specific nice titles. This paragraph could be cleaned up a tiny bit, but it's fine overall.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: This is good content - consider using this level of specificity and academic development throughout the rest of your statement.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Further, in my summer group project, I investigated the relationship between ASD and dyslexia and used an AQ test and nonsense reading task on 21 participants to measure the two disorders. We found a positive correlation, foreshadowed by a range of past studies. However the experiment introduced me to issues like co-morbidity and the difficulties of quantifying such unique and complicated disorders. This, along with reading Ben Goldacre's 'Bad Science' taught me about the importance of scientifically credible experiments and awareness of cognitive biases.
feedback_items.why_strong: This section provides specific methodology, clear results, identifies limitations and complexities, and links practical research to theoretical reading. It demonstrates scientific thinking and critical analysis.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The biggest problem with this statement is that there is no academic argument, reasoning, or logic displayed. The statement doesn't show the kind of student you are. The first two questions are particularly lacking compared to the third question, which is actually well done.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on demonstrating your academic thinking throughout. Use the third paragraph as your model - it shows specific research, methodology, results, and critical analysis. Apply this same level of academic rigor to the earlier sections.

subject: Economics
statement_full_text:
Question 1: Why do you want to study this course or subject?
Having grown up in fisheries outside Karachi before moving into the city, I have lived in contrasting economic and geographic environments. Specifically, in Karachi concentrated jobs and infrastructure access highlighted agglomeration economies, which inspired me to read LSE's 'Spatial Inequality, Regional Growth and Economic Geography'. I disagree with the theory of conditional convergence because it assumes poor regions will naturally grow faster and catch up due to diminishing returns on capital and technology. In my experience, the opposite occurred: the gap widened as the cities advanced at the expense of stagnation in outer regions.This led me to consider Thomas Piketty's argument in 'Capital in the Twenty First Century' that inequality widens as wealth concentrates when the rate of return on capital exceeds economic growth, favouring progressive wealth taxation. However, I argue that traditional wealth solutions such as progressive wealth and capital gains taxes are unlikely to fully resolve inequality - since they can be regressive and encourage avoidance. For example, France's ISF raised only about €5 billion, around 2% of tax receipts, before it was terminated in 2018. I now aim to explore how developing nations such as my own can achieve a higher GDP per capita through applied econometrics.
Question 2: How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?
After completing Stanford's MOOC on game theory,Jackson's remark, "where you are decides what you become," introduced me to how geography shapes economic outcomes. Reene Ong's study showed how people living in flood ridden environments in Kelantan, Malaysia are trapped in debt because of land loss and rising insurance premiums. I explored this further in my essay for the John Locke essay competition, arguing that it fuels disaster capitalism, privatisation, and inefficiency, ultimately constraining sustainable and equitable development in the Kelantan region. Acemoglu's 'Why Nations Fail' echoes this, by showing how institutional quality often exploits these spatially vulnerable people. Without breaking this cycle, the framework of an ideal economy free of indebtedness remains abstract. Drawing on this understanding, I led a delegation at the National Policy Conference, where I agreed with Acemoglu that institutions must be less concentrated, bypassing bureaucracy to promote equal participation.
At the Centre of Economic Research Pakistan's summer school, I further investigated how reducing inequality contributes to sustainable development in Pakistan. Using non-linear regression with regularisation, I analysed the relationship between a redistributive policy index and access to climate resilient infrastructure. I found that, although Pakistan's inequality has improved since 2013, unsustainable development persists. I therefore suggested environmental taxes, lowering VAT on energy bills, and subsidising renewable energy in underdeveloped areas to stimulate economic growth through targeted sectoral policies, as advocated by Ha-Joon Chang.
Attending a real estate masterclass by Dr. Hoeltken introduced me to evidence-based policy as a data driven approach for policy analysis. I sought to explore how different types of housing policies can influence inclusive economic outcomes. LSE's research stated that moderate regulation sustains tenant security without restraining supply, an argument reinforced by evidence that indexation prevents inflation-driven inefficiency. Ultimately this persuaded me that calibrated rent control systems, characterised by government intervention, provide higher macroeconomic outcomes to mixed systems by creating more responsible economic policies. While Diamond's work revealed long-term risks of embedded inequality and gentrification, I concluded that dynamic, carefully calibrated housing policies are necessary to mitigate inequality while remaining socially viable.
Question 3: What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?
Last summer, I undertook an independent project on the central bank's push toward digital currencies. The IMF's analysis of Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs) made me question whether technology alone can democratise finance since payment and financial inclusion policy continues to shape access and distribution within financial systems. My internship at JS Bank provided evidence for my point, transaction data through visualisation revealed that about 87% of cash-dependent communities often remain digitally excluded. I believe CBDCs could effectively reinforce the inequality they seek to narrow by resorting to a new form of financial hierarchy: requiring specific digital literacy and internet access. Simultaneously, I tutored junior sixth form Maths students on integration which has equipped me with the appropriate skillset for problem solving and data analysis. I hope to advance these skills to properly understand the intersection of environmental sustainability and economics in developing nations such as mine.

feedback_items.your_feedback: There are quite a few factual inaccuracies in the statement - this is a red flag. You need to do a full look-through of your theories because there are issues throughout, even in small details. For example, the ISF wealth tax - there is still a wealth tax in France, so this specific case needs correction.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Go through every theory, statistic, and factual claim in your statement and verify accuracy. Check your understanding of conditional convergence and other economic theories you reference.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You list so many different sources but don't give your argument time to develop. Because of this, you get to huge sweeping conclusions but haven't explained them properly - there's no proper supportive reasoning. It looks like you haven't really understood, so you're forcing in all these theories here and there. On a scale of 0-10 where 10 is best, this is a 4.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose fewer sources and develop each one thoroughly. Take time to explain the theory, your analysis, the methodology, and how it connects to your argument before moving to the next source.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Having grown up in fisheries outside Karachi
feedback_items.your_feedback: Fisheries is an industry - unless you grew up literally in a fishery farm, this doesn't make sense. Do you mean rural areas? Because it's so unusual phrasing, readers won't immediately understand without more context.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify whether you mean rural fishing communities or if you actually lived on a fishery farm. Provide clearer context about your geographic background.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Having grown up in fisheries outside Karachi before moving into the city, I have lived in contrasting economic and geographic environments.
feedback_items.your_feedback: About 80% of statements start with something like 'I visited rural places and I lived in urban places.' It's just a nothing thing, and in your case you have so many different ideas you couldn't develop, so you might want to remove this and start differently.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut this generic opening and start directly with your academic interest - perhaps with the LSE book or a specific economic concept that intrigued you.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I disagree with the theory of conditional convergence because it assumes poor regions will naturally grow faster and catch up due to diminishing returns on capital and technology. In my experience, the opposite occurred
feedback_items.your_feedback: You shouldn't be disagreeing with something while getting conditional convergence kind of wrong because you haven't understood it properly. This is a red flag. Also, what experience? You can't just claim personal experience contradicts established economic theory without proper backing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If you disagree with a theory, you must: 1) demonstrate full understanding of it first, 2) cite another academic paper that presents an alternative view, 3) explain why that alternative makes more sense in your specific context with proper variables and evidence. Never rely on vague 'personal experience' to contradict theory.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This led me to consider Thomas Piketty's argument in 'Capital in the Twenty First Century' that inequality widens as wealth concentrates when the rate of return on capital exceeds economic growth, favouring progressive wealth taxation. However, I argue that traditional wealth solutions such as progressive wealth and capital gains taxes are unlikely to fully resolve inequality
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're jumping to Piketty suddenly, taking just one sentence to explain the broad general idea, but there's so much more going on. You're only picking out the most basic, descriptive idea. Then you say 'however I argue' with no backing whatsoever - based on what? In one paragraph you've said 'I disagree,' 'I think this,' 'in my experience,' and 'however I argue' with almost no supporting evidence.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: When introducing a major work like Piketty's, spend time explaining the methodology, key evidence, and nuances of the argument. Then, if you want to critique it, cite specific alternative research or data - don't just assert your disagreement.

feedback_items.weak_passage: For example, France's ISF raised only about €5 billion, around 2% of tax receipts, before it was terminated in 2018.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You can't just chuck in France out of nowhere as a stat and be done with it. This is a very specific case study - if you're using it as evidence, you need to explain the context and why this particular example is relevant to your broader argument about developing nations.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either develop this France example properly with context about why the ISF was reformed and what that tells us, or find a more relevant example from a developing nation context.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I now aim to explore how developing nations such as my own can achieve a higher GDP per capita through applied econometrics.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Where is the applied econometrics you're going to use? And what do you mean higher GDP per capita - that's just one metric, it's nothing. This conclusion is too vague and doesn't follow from what you've discussed.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If you want to discuss econometric approaches, name specific methods or models. And GDP per capita alone is a weak goal - discuss what aspects of development or inequality you want to address specifically.

feedback_items.weak_passage: After completing Stanford's MOOC on game theory,Jackson's remark, "where you are decides what you become," introduced me to how geography shapes economic outcomes.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Who is Jackson? You can't just bring in some random person and expect everybody to know who they are. Also, this quote is under-explained - what does that mean exactly? You're looking at a quote and then just moving on without development.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide Jackson's full name and credentials, and explain the quote's significance in the context of economic geography with specific examples.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I explored this further in my essay for the John Locke essay competition, arguing that it fuels disaster capitalism, privatisation, and inefficiency, ultimately constraining sustainable and equitable development in the Kelantan region.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What does 'it' mean here - do you mean flood-ridden environments? This reads as just a list of things without explanation. You haven't told me what your conclusion was, what readings you used, or developed any of these concepts. What am I supposed to do, just look at this list and agree with you?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain your essay's core argument clearly, mention 1-2 key sources you used, and walk through your reasoning. Don't just list outcomes - explain the causal mechanisms you identified.

feedback_items.weak_passage: transaction data through visualisation revealed that about 87% of cash-dependent communities often remain digitally excluded.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Where did that 87% statistic come from? What is a cash-dependent community - are you going to explain that? What were you looking at exactly? There are so many questions raised by this claim without proper sourcing or definition.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cite the source of your data, define what constitutes a 'cash-dependent community' in your analysis, and explain your methodology for reaching this conclusion.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The whole statement reads as very descriptive because you're only picking out broad general ideas from sources. You take a sentence to explain what the general ideas are, but there's so much more going on. Therefore, your statement lacks analytical depth and reads like surface-level summaries.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: For each source, go deeper than the main thesis - discuss methodology, analyze specific data or arguments, and show critical engagement with limitations and alternatives.

feedback_items.your_feedback: There's no section which is clean. There's no section I can tell you to look at as a sample because all of it is a bit messy, under-explained, and needs work. It needs a lot of tidying up for the courses you're applying for - unfortunately it's not quite where you need it to be.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Do a complete restructure: pick 3-4 key ideas/sources maximum, develop each one thoroughly with proper context, methodology, analysis, and conclusions before moving to the next one. Quality over quantity.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You do look like you've done a lot of reading with the huge amount of sources included. That's impressive. However, the execution needs significant work to match the breadth of your research.
feedback_items.strong_passage: You've included a wide range of relevant economic sources from Piketty to Acemoglu to Ha-Joon Chang, covering development economics, inequality, and institutional theory.
feedback_items.why_strong: The breadth of reading demonstrates genuine engagement with the field and exposure to major contemporary debates in economics.

subject: PPE
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course or subject?

I am driven by a conviction that rising conflict, inequality and polarisation around the world is drawing us towards Arendt's "banality of evil", and moreover that PPE is uniquely suited to help me challenge this.
I concurred with Frankfurt's "On Bullshit", where a disregard for the truthfulness (not the same as lying) of the media both undermines our discourse and economic agency.
Expanding on this, I participated in the NEULondon essay competition, writing about the structural incentives of social media that penalise integrity as well as the phenomenon of "memes" being used as ironic rhetorical tools and therefore undermining legitimate debate, for which I received a distinction. I disagreed with Chomsky's view that economic elites collude to "manufacture consent", instead, I believe polarisation in our media is rising precisely because there is no centre of control - and that this empowers extremists.
To what extent does imperfect information cause war? Almost entirely, I decided, after encountering the concept of ESSs presented by Dawkins, drawing heavily from Game Theory, modelling intrastate behaviour. I used Spaniel's framework to apply this to the Ukraine War, where, despite incurring costs by continuing to fight, bargaining frictions caused by imperfect information (as both sides' ability to fight is contingent on unpredictable factors such as foreign aid) elude solution. Yet, my view was challenged in "Notes From the Underground" where Dostoevsky challenges the essentiality of human rationality, which led me to question the central assumptions of neoclassical economics. Dostoevsky's view that over-rationalising our decisions dishonestly distances ourselves from our morality to me highlights the dangers of the "banality of evil" ever-present in our politics.

How have your qualifications or studies prepared you to study this subject?
In A-Level history, my teacher introduced me to the fascinating concept of "Napoleon's dictum", which argues that a person can be understood through the lens of the world when they were 20. I related this to notions of whether our wills can ever truly be "free" if they are so strongly influenced by the environment, a view I encountered from Sapolsky on the 'Within Reason' podcast. In my interpretation of "The Stranger", the moral and psychological control society seeks to impose on Meursault through his trial struck me as another example of social determinism. Moreover, this has led me to question whether freedom is paradoxical in a determinist universe: non-random events must be determined, but neither collapsing into pure randomness nor pure determinism seem to bring about freedom.

What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and how have these experiences been useful?
What is the best way to develop a poor country? I initially agreed with Acemoglu/Robinson's central thesis that inclusive institutions (such as those found in the settler-colonial structure of the US compared to quasi-feudal colonial México) are conducive to economic growth, which I found built of off Smith's initial observation that merchants and businessmen would try to rig markets in their favour. In my role as a writer for Etonomics, I argued that extractive institutions (such as the License Raj in India) are immoral because they perpetuate unequal economic control, exercised through elite networks. Sen's humanist capabilities-led approach took a similar approach to criticising political and economic unfreedoms; I found his argument for redefining development in terms of substantive freedoms compelling.
Leading my school's MUN and philosophy societies, I researched democratic backsliding around the world. Learning about crackdowns on judicial independence, the separation of powers and military coups in sub-Saharan Africa affirmed my belief in the deontological and utilitarian reasons for free speech outlined in Mill's "On Liberty", which was a subject of study in Balliol College's Floreat programme.
Ultimately, PPE is vital for untangling the disparate causes of inequality, unfreedom and conflict present in the world.

feedback_items.your_feedback: For your age group, you are one of the better writers that I've come across. Your writing style is really excellent - it's rare to find this level of writing ability at your age. That is exceptional, really great.
feedback_items.strong_passage: The entire statement demonstrates sophisticated writing with strong vocabulary, complex sentence structures, and philosophical depth unusual for this level.
feedback_items.why_strong: The writing flows naturally, uses academic language appropriately, and shows intellectual maturity. The student can articulate complex ideas clearly and engagingly.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Do I think you overuse rhetorical questions a little bit? Yes, but that's a taste thing, neither here nor there. Overall your personal statement reads really nicely, clearly shows interest, good level and good range of theories, good academic content.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider reducing the number of rhetorical questions slightly, but this is a minor stylistic preference rather than a significant issue.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Could you go into a little bit more depth here and there in certain theories and develop things out a little bit more? Yes. Would it be being a little bit picky? Also yes. I think what you've done is sufficient. It's not the best personal statement I've seen amongst PPE submissions, but it's not going to hold you back.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: You could develop individual theories with more depth, but at this point don't spend more time on it. Focus on other parts of your application like the TSA.

feedback_items.your_feedback: No obvious errors, shows enthusiasm, and you've done really well. I am impressed. I think the statement is good enough and you shouldn't spend more time on it - focus on TSA and other application elements instead.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Prioritize TSA preparation over further statement revisions. If applying from a state school with strong grades and decent TSA, you're a very hopeful candidate.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The opening with Arendt's 'banality of evil' is strong and shows you're engaging with serious philosophical concepts. The connection to Frankfurt's 'On Bullshit' and media discourse demonstrates sophisticated thinking.
feedback_items.strong_passage: I am driven by a conviction that rising conflict, inequality and polarisation around the world is drawing us towards Arendt's "banality of evil", and moreover that PPE is uniquely suited to help me challenge this. I concurred with Frankfurt's "On Bullshit", where a disregard for the truthfulness (not the same as lying) of the media both undermines our discourse and economic agency.
feedback_items.why_strong: Strong philosophical framing that immediately establishes intellectual seriousness and connects abstract philosophy to contemporary political issues.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Your NEULondon essay on social media structural incentives shows original thinking. The disagreement with Chomsky demonstrates you can engage critically with major thinkers and form your own views.
feedback_items.strong_passage: I disagreed with Chomsky's view that economic elites collude to "manufacture consent", instead, I believe polarisation in our media is rising precisely because there is no centre of control - and that this empowers extremists.
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows critical thinking by respectfully disagreeing with a major theorist and providing an alternative explanation backed by reasoning.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The application of game theory and ESS concepts to the Ukraine War is impressive. You're taking theoretical frameworks and applying them to current events, which shows exactly the kind of thinking PPE tutors want to see.
feedback_items.strong_passage: To what extent does imperfect information cause war? Almost entirely, I decided, after encountering the concept of ESSs presented by Dawkins, drawing heavily from Game Theory, modelling intrastate behaviour. I used Spaniel's framework to apply this to the Ukraine War, where, despite incurring costs by continuing to fight, bargaining frictions caused by imperfect information (as both sides' ability to fight is contingent on unpredictable factors such as foreign aid) elude solution.
feedback_items.why_strong: Demonstrates ability to apply theoretical concepts to real-world situations, showing both understanding of game theory and current affairs knowledge.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Bringing in Dostoevsky to challenge neoclassical economics assumptions shows genuine interdisciplinary thinking - connecting literature, philosophy, and economics in a meaningful way.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Yet, my view was challenged in "Notes From the Underground" where Dostoevsky challenges the essentiality of human rationality, which led me to question the central assumptions of neoclassical economics. Dostoevsky's view that over-rationalising our decisions dishonestly distances ourselves from our morality to me highlights the dangers of the "banality of evil" ever-present in our politics.
feedback_items.why_strong: Excellent interdisciplinary connection that circles back to the opening theme, showing coherent thinking across philosophy, literature, and economics.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The exploration of free will and determinism through Napoleon's dictum, Sapolsky, and Camus shows you're grappling with fundamental philosophical questions. This is exactly what philosophy tutors want to see.
feedback_items.strong_passage: I related this to notions of whether our wills can ever truly be "free" if they are so strongly influenced by the environment, a view I encountered from Sapolsky on the 'Within Reason' podcast. In my interpretation of "The Stranger", the moral and psychological control society seeks to impose on Meursault through his trial struck me as another example of social determinism. Moreover, this has led me to question whether freedom is paradoxical in a determinist universe: non-random events must be determined, but neither collapsing into pure randomness nor pure determinism seem to bring about freedom.
feedback_items.why_strong: Demonstrates deep philosophical thinking about free will and determinism, connecting multiple sources and showing genuine puzzlement over a fundamental question.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The engagement with development economics through Acemoglu/Robinson, Smith, and Sen shows solid understanding of major debates in the field. Your writing for Etonomics demonstrates you're actively engaging with these ideas.
feedback_items.strong_passage: I initially agreed with Acemoglu/Robinson's central thesis that inclusive institutions (such as those found in the settler-colonial structure of the US compared to quasi-feudal colonial México) are conducive to economic growth, which I found built of off Smith's initial observation that merchants and businessmen would try to rig markets in their favour.
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows understanding of major economic development theories and traces intellectual lineages between thinkers, demonstrating historical knowledge of economic thought.

feedback_items.your_feedback: MUN and philosophy societies leadership combined with research on democratic backsliding shows practical engagement with political issues. The connection to Mill and the Floreat programme is good.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Leading my school's MUN and philosophy societies, I researched democratic backsliding around the world. Learning about crackdowns on judicial independence, the separation of powers and military coups in sub-Saharan Africa affirmed my belief in the deontological and utilitarian reasons for free speech outlined in Mill's "On Liberty", which was a subject of study in Balliol College's Floreat programme.
feedback_items.why_strong: Combines practical leadership with research and connects it to Mill's philosophy, showing how theory informs understanding of current political problems.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You're just on the borderline of being too shallow in certain places. If you have some character space, develop out some of the stuff you've already got rather than adding completely new content.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If you have extra space, deepen your existing points rather than adding new theories or examples. Pick 1-2 key arguments and add another sentence explaining methodology or implications.

subject: Theoretical Physics
statement_full_text:
My interest in Physics began by watching Sean Carroll's lectures, "The Biggest Ideas in the Universe" which taught me how mathematics can shape our understanding of physics. Carroll introduced Lagrangian mechanics, a framework that uses the Euler-Lagrange equation to describe motion by finding the path of least action. I found it fascinating that more complex physics can be described through different models, realising that it extends far beyond Newtonian principles. I was amazed to also learn that the path integral, which considers all possible particle paths, allows the same concept to transcend classical mechanics and be generalised in quantum interactions. I noticed how theoretical physics may reveal links between the macroscopic and microscopic scales. I then explored other theoretical principles in Kumar's 'Quantum'. I was intrigued by the way complex numbers encode the probabilistic nature of quantum systems and capture both phase and amplitude. Through this, I recognised the many areas I'm eager to explore and developed an appreciation for how physics relates to abstract mathematics to provide more profound explanations of nature.

During the Oxford Particle Physics Masterclass, I found it gratifying to see theory in practice through applied mathematics and data analysis. In trying to estimate the D0 meson lifetime, we were introduced to Gaussian fits, which modelled the meson's signal distribution, distinguishing it from background noise. Our calculated value was slightly off, but by constantly adjusting the IP bounds, we saw how the results shifted closer to the true value. This not only showed me the importance of persistence in problem-solving but also improved my understanding of how quantitative methods test theories. Building on these problem-solving experiences, I furthered my knowledge of Feynman diagrams by learning about Lorentz vectors, which describe the energy and momentum of particles at each vertex, and how to represent them in Python. This process made me realise I had previously overlooked the importance of coding, inspiring me to create projects in Python, such as a SUVAT calculator or an SHM simulation governed by differential equations. Having some experience will help me adapt to the computational aspects of the course.

My inspiration to enter Caius Explore stemmed from my time at Oxford, where we went over the Bullet Cluster and its evidence for dark matter. Initially, I regarded dark matter as more speculative rather than a concrete theory in physics. However, I was struck by the vast amount of observations and theoretical candidates that we have. For example, galactic rotation curves reveal an effect that matter alone cannot explain, whilst candidates such as axions are theorised to be necessary for the formation of early cosmic structures. Through participating I concluded that physics thrives on constantly new ideas, requiring adaptability and inspiring me to consider the other challenges driving modern physics. As a result, I read Rovelli's "Reality Is Not What It Seems" which explores the search for quantum gravity. I was struck by the fact that two established theories (general relativity and quantum mechanics) remain incompatible ,despite extensive research. Whilst I was able to piece some ideas on his loop quantum gravity, engaging with these topics highlighted the knowledge I lack, which I hope to develop on this course.

I find engagement with the Physics community on a global level necessary to broaden my perspective on research in different fields. Learning Spanish demonstrates my desire to access this knowledge; aside from reading articles on 'Science Daily' and 'Quanta Magazine' , reading them in Spanish helps me work on my critical thinking by exposing me to different perspectives and ways of presenting ideas. Contributing locally by hosting a STEM club at a school lets me share my enthusiasm whilst enhancing my leadership skills and skills to explain concepts clearly.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The biggest problem is that it's not very dense with information. If I were to rewrite this in what I think is good English, I would lose 50% of it. Half of the stuff is good content, but half is fluff. You probably think you've written loads, but I would say half is fluff and half is actual content. On a scale where 10 is best, this is probably a 6.5.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reduce the fluff and replace it with content equal to or better than what you currently have. If you could double the actual academic content by cutting filler language, you'd have an excellent statement.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Your topics are pretty interesting, you've got a good range, a fair amount of development. You clearly come across as somebody who's done more than A Level content, so positioning and leveling is fairly good.
feedback_items.strong_passage: The choice of topics (Lagrangian mechanics, path integrals, quantum gravity, particle physics) and the range of sources (Sean Carroll, Kumar, Rovelli) show engagement beyond A-level.
feedback_items.why_strong: Demonstrates ambition and genuine interest in advanced physics concepts, showing readiness for university-level study.

feedback_items.weak_passage: which taught me how mathematics can shape our understanding of physics.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Is that the world's greatest conclusion or insight to draw from a series of lectures that I'm sure discussed many more interesting things? Obviously not. You can see that mathematics and physics are related - it's not an enlightening thing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace this obvious observation with a specific insight from the lectures - perhaps a particular mathematical structure that illuminated a physical phenomenon in an unexpected way.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I found it fascinating that more complex physics can be described through different models, realising that it extends far beyond Newtonian principles.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is kind of meaningless - it could be replaced with absolutely anything. It's not a developed conclusion, it's just saying 'this may be the case.' It's like saying it may rain tomorrow.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either cut this entirely or make it specific: explain what specific complex phenomena Lagrangian mechanics explains that Newtonian mechanics cannot handle well.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I noticed how theoretical physics may reveal links between the macroscopic and microscopic scales.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You could replace this with absolutely anything. Do you see what I mean? It's not a developed kind of anything sentence. There's not a conclusion. It's just saying this may be the case.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut this sentence - it adds nothing. If you want to discuss scale-bridging, give a concrete example from your reading.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Through this, I recognised the many areas I'm eager to explore and developed an appreciation for how physics relates to abstract mathematics to provide more profound explanations of nature.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is final sentence fluff. All I'm really getting from this first paragraph is that this student believes physics and maths are related - that's your only insight. The rest is some descriptive points about frameworks, path integrals, and complex numbers, but nothing developed.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this concluding fluff sentence entirely. Use that space to develop one of your earlier points with more depth.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My interest in Physics began by watching Sean Carroll's lectures...Through this, I recognised the many areas I'm eager to explore
feedback_items.your_feedback: If I were to summarize this first paragraph, I would say: this student believes physics and maths are related. That's the only insight. Then you have descriptive points about multiple frameworks, path integral stuff, and complex number stuff. I could rewrite that in about 4 sentences.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense this paragraph to focus on one or two concepts with real depth. For example, pick either Lagrangian mechanics OR quantum probability amplitudes and explain it properly with mathematical insight.

feedback_items.weak_passage: During the Oxford Particle Physics Masterclass, I found it gratifying to see theory in practice through applied mathematics and data analysis.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What is gratifying about that? I'm not totally sure. It's not a very Cambridge statement or an Imperial or UCL statement - you're going for a tough subject here and this language is too soft.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut 'I found it gratifying' - just state what you did and learned. Start with the meson lifetime estimation directly.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This not only showed me the importance of persistence in problem-solving but also improved my understanding of how quantitative methods test theories.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What does that actually mean? Why are you using so many words to write something that's not complicated enough? You're just using a lot of words to state something obvious without real substance.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this and use the space to explain a specific technical insight from the masterclass - perhaps something about systematic vs statistical errors, or the physics behind the D0 meson decay.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In trying to estimate the D0 meson lifetime, we were introduced to Gaussian fits, which modelled the meson's signal distribution, distinguishing it from background noise. Our calculated value was slightly off, but by constantly adjusting the IP bounds, we saw how the results shifted closer to the true value.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This section is actually fine - it shows specific technical work you did with data analysis and shows understanding of experimental physics methodology.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: This is good content - consider expanding slightly on what you learned about experimental uncertainty or statistical methods rather than the generic persistence comment that follows.
feedback_items.strong_passage: In trying to estimate the D0 meson lifetime, we were introduced to Gaussian fits, which modelled the meson's signal distribution, distinguishing it from background noise. Our calculated value was slightly off, but by constantly adjusting the IP bounds, we saw how the results shifted closer to the true value.
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows hands-on experience with data analysis and experimental methods, demonstrates technical understanding of particle physics techniques.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Initially, I regarded dark matter as more speculative rather than a concrete theory in physics.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is honest and shows intellectual development - you're showing how your understanding evolved, which is good.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Initially, I regarded dark matter as more speculative rather than a concrete theory in physics. However, I was struck by the vast amount of observations and theoretical candidates that we have. For example, galactic rotation curves reveal an effect that matter alone cannot explain, whilst candidates such as axions are theorised to be necessary for the formation of early cosmic structures.
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows genuine intellectual journey from skepticism to understanding, backed by specific examples of evidence and theoretical candidates.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I find engagement with the Physics community on a global level necessary to broaden my perspective on research in different fields. Learning Spanish demonstrates my desire to access this knowledge; aside from reading articles on 'Science Daily' and 'Quanta Magazine' , reading them in Spanish helps me work on my critical thinking by exposing me to different perspectives and ways of presenting ideas.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This last paragraph is fine but nothing special - it's the same paragraph I've seen repeated in multiple statements. The stuff about reading articles on Science Daily and Quanta Magazine is just listing. You should at least mention an article on what was particularly interesting.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Ask your tutor if they'll mention STEM club in the reference - if yes, remove it from here. For the Spanish/articles, either cut it or make it specific by naming one particularly interesting article and what you learned.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Language issues throughout - why is it taking you so many words to write something that's not that complex? You're clearly smart and know what you're talking about, it's just not enough content for the space you're using. You're using a lot of words to write something that's not complicated enough.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Go through and ask yourself for every sentence: could I say this in fewer words? Does this sentence contain a genuine insight or is it filler? If you removed half the words, could you fit in twice as much actual physics content?

feedback_items.your_feedback: When it really comes down to it, if you asked someone to extract all the good points from this statement - ignoring fluff, repetition, filler language, or anything too obvious like 'math and physics are related' - I don't think there would be too many points. Your sections are interesting and fairly well developed, but you're not making as many substantive points as you think.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Use an AI to extract just your substantive academic points. You'll probably find fewer than you expect. Then focus on adding more depth to existing points rather than more filler language around them.

feedback_items.your_feedback: There are no red flags in here, nothing wrong with it whatsoever. If you wanted to focus more on admissions tests, you could do that. If you wanted to have another go at the statement, I'm sure I could get around to it before your deadline if I have time. It's your choice.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: The statement is acceptable as-is. You could either focus on TSA/admissions tests now, or do one more revision to increase content density. Both are valid choices depending on your timeline.

subject: Medicine
statement_full_text:
Few things are more difficult to watch than the body undermining its own survival. When my mum was diagnosed with Evans syndrome and Immune Thrombocytopaenia, it felt like witnessing a system built for survival repeatedly fail her. Medicine, to me, is the discipline that confronts this failure head on – not to promise perfection but to sustain, to stabilise and to restore some order to a broken mechanism. I came to appreciate how disease doesn't just disrupt the body; it disrupts a whole life. This understanding was deepened when reading When Breath Becomes Air which taught me that medicine is not only about fighting illness but also preserving dignity and meaning for those with uncertainty, reminding us that while death is inevitable and beyond out control, how we confront it is a profoundly human choice that connects us all – lessons that have stayed with me as I support my mum through her ongoing journey.
This personal connection has driven me to pursue academic challenges that deepen my understanding beyond the classroom. Among these, the Homerton Biology Challenge was particularly rewarding; I delved into the question "Why do we dream?" where I explored the neuroscience behind dreaming, earning a Distinction and A Badge of Merit for original thought. The challenge sharpened my ability to explore intricate biological concepts with curiosity and attention to detail. Similarly, the STEM SMART programme connected me with Cambridge lecturers whose guidance fuelled my enthusiasm for rigorous research and a clearer understanding of the bigger academic picture. This is evident when my studies of meiosis and genetic variation at A-Level led me to discover the film The Birth of IVF, which revealed Jean Purdy's vital yet overlooked contribution to IVF's development, inspiring my Newnham Wool Prize essay The Other Diagnosis, where I explored the historical challenges women faced in medicine. Alongside consistent success in Challenges and Olympiads, these experiences have cultivated the analytical mindset and commitment I know will be essential in a medical career.
At Kingston Hospital's Head and Neck Stop Clinic, I witnessed an ENT consultant gently break the news to a lively patient that a lump in her throat might be cancerous. Seeing her shift from joy to quiet resignation brought home just how vulnerable patients are and how being a doctor means offering not just a diagnosis but real compassion and emotional support. This human side of medicine stayed with me when in a pharmacy, I recognised one of my mother's medications -Mycophenolate Mofetil - a familiar face in an unfamiliar place - reminding me how a wealth of resources connects countless lives through the shared care and responsibility of many healthcare professionals. Volunteering at a special needs school challenged me to think creatively and with empathy, understanding that true care often means going beyond standard approaches to truly represent each individual's needs.
My involvement in the Imperial Science in Medicine Prize, where I co-developed OxyDose - a smart, wearable patch that delivers rapid, discreet oxygen support during episodes of breathlessness - taught me the value of teamwork and practical solutions focused on real patient needs. Fundraising for UK-Med and running docquickies, a Tiktok platform simplifying medical topics, showed me how even small efforts - whether raising awareness or simplifying complex ideas can meaningfully impact the wider community. It affirmed my drive to make a difference, however modest, beyond the typical. Medicine might not always cure, but it always cares. I want to be that steady hand, offering support when it matters most.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The running theme throughout your entire statement is that you're listing things - listing a lot of skills that you claim to have without much evidence and backing for it. These are skills they should be inferring from what you've written, not you telling them from what you've not written.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Show, don't tell. Instead of saying 'this sharpened my ability' or 'taught me creativity', describe what you actually did in enough detail that the reader can infer these qualities themselves.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Your points as a whole are a little bit underdeveloped. I'm going to be pretty straight to the point because it's the easiest way to get my point across. I'm sorry if this sounds harsh - I have to say this to everyone.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Take each experience or book you mention and spend more time explaining: What exactly did you learn? What was your methodology? What conclusions did you reach? What could be improved?

feedback_items.weak_passage: Few things are more difficult to watch than the body undermining its own survival.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This entire first paragraph is a little bit too poetic, it's too many words to say it. The first sentence is just totally useless - just go in with the second one about when your mom was diagnosed.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete the first sentence entirely. Start with 'When my mum was diagnosed...' which is more direct and equally impactful.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Medicine, to me, is the discipline that confronts this failure head on – not to promise perfection but to sustain, to stabilise and to restore some order to a broken mechanism.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a little bit too wishy-washy. You're going for fairly academic places, so I would lean into the academic side of it a little bit more rather than this poetic language.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Make this more concrete and academic. Perhaps discuss specific aspects of autoimmune disease pathology or treatment approaches rather than abstract metaphors.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I came to appreciate how disease doesn't just disrupt the body; it disrupts a whole life.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I'm not really sure that sentence does much, because I don't know how you came to appreciate that. I'm not really sure what the difference is between disrupting body and life - it seems sort of samey unless you're going to explain it, and you don't explain it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either delete this sentence or make it concrete with an example: how specifically did your mother's illness disrupt her life beyond the physical symptoms? What did you observe?

feedback_items.weak_passage: This understanding was deepened when reading When Breath Becomes Air
feedback_items.your_feedback: You say this understanding was deepened, but you haven't given an understanding yet. So it's difficult to say what was deepened. It's good that you bring in a book though.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either establish your initial understanding first, or just jump straight to the book: 'Reading When Breath Becomes Air taught me that...' without the claim about deepening.

feedback_items.weak_passage: lessons that have stayed with me as I support my mum through her ongoing journey.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You've already mentioned your mom's illness, so I would just cut this part out because it feels like it's getting repetitive now.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence - end the paragraph with the lessons from the book without circling back to your mother again.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Few things are more difficult to watch than the body undermining its own survival...lessons that have stayed with me as I support my mum through her ongoing journey.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole first paragraph could be shortened by about half, maybe adding something else in its place that's a little bit more developed, showing what was your original understanding and how it was actually deepened.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense to: mum's diagnosis, specific medical insight about autoimmune disease, one key lesson from When Breath Becomes Air with detail. Should fit in half the space.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This personal connection has driven me to pursue academic challenges that deepen my understanding beyond the classroom.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Just cut out that sentence. It's a pointless intro sentence. I've read the previous paragraph so I should be able to just follow on straight away.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this transition sentence entirely and start directly with the Homerton Biology Challenge.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Among these, the Homerton Biology Challenge was particularly rewarding; I delved into the question "Why do we dream?" where I explored the neuroscience behind dreaming, earning a Distinction and A Badge of Merit for original thought.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I'm not a fan of including the question title in the essay. I would rather you just explain straight away what the conclusion was. You earned a distinction and badge - that doesn't matter as much as telling me what your conclusion was. I still have no idea what your methodology was, what your evidence and supporting points were.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace with: 'In the Homerton Biology Challenge, I concluded that [your finding about dreams]. I explored [methodology] using [sources], finding that [specific insight].' Cut the awards - focus on substance.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The challenge sharpened my ability to explore intricate biological concepts with curiosity and attention to detail.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is an example of what I mean by you telling me the abilities you have, as opposed to me just learning it. If you explain well what intricate biological concepts you actually used in this challenge, then I would naturally think this person has talents in biology and curiosity and attention to detail.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence entirely. Replace with actual details about the biological concepts you engaged with, and the reader will infer the qualities naturally.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Similarly, the STEM SMART programme connected me with Cambridge lecturers whose guidance fuelled my enthusiasm for rigorous research and a clearer understanding of the bigger academic picture.
feedback_items.your_feedback: 'Whose guidance fueled my enthusiasm for rigorous research and a clearer understanding of the big academic picture' is the most vague thing I've ever read. I don't know what that means - what enthusiasm for what, and what big picture?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Be specific: What did you actually learn from these Cambridge lecturers? What research did you discuss? What specific aspect of medicine or biology did they illuminate?

feedback_items.weak_passage: This is evident when my studies of meiosis and genetic variation at A-Level led me to discover the film The Birth of IVF
feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't think that's a very natural thing - did you study meiosis and then learn something interesting there and wanted to learn more? I would just go straight in with the film. I know you studied that at A Level.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete 'This is evident when my studies of meiosis and genetic variation at A-Level led me to' and just start: 'I watched The Birth of IVF, which revealed...'

feedback_items.weak_passage: which revealed Jean Purdy's vital yet overlooked contribution to IVF's development, inspiring my Newnham Wool Prize essay The Other Diagnosis, where I explored the historical challenges women faced in medicine.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I would quite like to know what the contribution is and what your thoughts on it are. You can't just leave that and assume they know what it is. Then you say this inspired your essay where you explored challenges women faced - but you don't tell me what the challenges were, any interesting conclusions, any interesting research you came across.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain: What was Purdy's specific contribution? What were 2-3 key challenges you identified in your essay? What did you conclude about these historical barriers?

feedback_items.weak_passage: Alongside consistent success in Challenges and Olympiads, these experiences have cultivated the analytical mindset and commitment I know will be essential in a medical career.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole last sentence is you just listing out things that you think you have - analytical mindset and commitment. I should be able to get that regardless from what you've written, not from you telling me.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this entire concluding sentence. If your experiences are well-described, the reader will infer these qualities without you stating them.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Seeing her shift from joy to quiet resignation brought home just how vulnerable patients are and how being a doctor means offering not just a diagnosis but real compassion and emotional support.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I understand what you're trying to do - there's a list of things they want to see in you being a doctor - but I'm not sure that this is the best point ever or that well explained. Is there anything else you can mention that's more tied into the personality skills they're looking for?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: This is acceptable but could be stronger. Consider whether you observed something more specific about communication techniques or patient-centered care approaches.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This human side of medicine stayed with me when in a pharmacy, I recognised one of my mother's medications -Mycophenolate Mofetil - a familiar face in an unfamiliar place - reminding me how a wealth of resources connects countless lives through the shared care and responsibility of many healthcare professionals.
feedback_items.your_feedback: It feels a bit like you're trying to shove in definitions of what you're supposed to care about or what is important. I'm not sure about that part.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: This reads as forced - either make it more personal and specific about what you actually thought/learned, or cut it entirely. The 'wealth of resources' language is too generic.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Volunteering at a special needs school challenged me to think creatively and with empathy, understanding that true care often means going beyond standard approaches to truly represent each individual's needs.
feedback_items.your_feedback: It just reads like a list - I saw it here, I saw it here. There's just not enough detail. You're not going to tell me what exactly it was, what experience it was? It reads like a summary - like I know all the things I have to say and I'm going to say them regardless of how it ties in with individual experience.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Give one specific example: What did you do with a particular child? What standard approach didn't work? What creative solution did you try? What was the result?

feedback_items.weak_passage: My involvement in the Imperial Science in Medicine Prize, where I co-developed OxyDose - a smart, wearable patch that delivers rapid, discreet oxygen support during episodes of breathlessness - taught me the value of teamwork and practical solutions focused on real patient needs.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I would love to hear about how you developed that - it sounds really interesting! But instead you just say it taught you the value of teamwork and practical solutions. I know that - you must have worked in a team. Maybe instead say: I developed this thing, this is how we did it, this was a challenge, we got over it, this is what we could do in the future.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on the actual development process: What was the technical challenge? How did your team solve it? What did you specifically contribute? What would you improve with more time?

feedback_items.weak_passage: Fundraising for UK-Med and running docquickies, a Tiktok platform simplifying medical topics, showed me how even small efforts - whether raising awareness or simplifying complex ideas can meaningfully impact the wider community. It affirmed my drive to make a difference, however modest, beyond the typical.
feedback_items.your_feedback: It's fine that you did fundraising and the TikTok platform, but with you saying exactly how you impact the community, it's not that useful. 'Meaningfully impact the wider community' is too vague without specifics.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Provide concrete impact: How much did you raise? How many people watch your TikTok? What feedback have you received? What specific medical topic did you simplify and why?

feedback_items.weak_passage: Medicine might not always cure, but it always cares. I want to be that steady hand, offering support when it matters most.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I'm gonna go ahead and tell you to cut that. It's just too cliche. I'm not sure about that conclusion - you're bookending it with this kind of poetic, wishy-washy language.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this conclusion entirely. It's too generic and doesn't add anything after your specific experiences. Either end with OxyDose or write a more personal, specific concluding thought.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't develop your points nearly enough. If you reworked those sections, made everything less listy, cut out all the skills explanations, and developed some of these points, it would be an excellent personal statement because you've done a lot and read a lot. Your points are interesting - just a few issues here and there with execution.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Major revision needed: 1) Cut all soft skills listings, 2) Add specific details/methodology/conclusions to each experience, 3) Remove poetic language, 4) Show rather than tell your qualities through detailed description.
